Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: County supervisors learned of this from reporting in The Standard.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: learned of this from reporting in The Standard

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Humboldt supervisors voted to send a revised version of the letter; the county did not provide a copy to The Standard.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: voted to send a revised version of the letter

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to the program’s website, social services staffers verify that those who use TAP will be received at their destination by a relative, friend, or appropriate agency.
Los Angeles and Sacramento counties are the two other most popular California destinations, according to SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency.
Document Sources.Name of Source: SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency
Document Sources.Source Justification: according to SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: “We were dismayed to learn that our small, rural county was among the top three destinations in the state where people experiencing homelessness were sent by the program,” states a draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website.
Document Sources.Source Justification: draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The aim isn’t to achieve a goal. It’s to get you out of our town, and it’s cheaper than arresting you,” Boden said. “The No. 1 answer to homelessness is to make them disappear. Then mayors write letters back and forth: ‘Stop sending your people here.’ Then it turns out they’re sending their people here. It shows the ridiculousness of us not trying to address why people are on the streets.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: homeless advocate with the Western Regional Advocacy Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: homeless advocate with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Our TAP program works really well, and hopefully San Francisco can go back to more — not just dumping — but assisting and actually helping people get help,” Humboldt Supervisor Rex Bohn said at Tuesday’s board meeting.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Humboldt Supervisor; at Tuesday’s board meeting

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: When asked for comment, the San Francisco mayor’s office said it had not received the letter.
